metadata.title: Found Graph Data and Planted Vertex Covers
metadata.author: Austin R. Benson, Jon Kleinberg
metadata.abstract: A typical way in which network data is recorded is to measure all interactions involving a specified set of core nodes, which produces a graph containing this core together with a potentially larger set of fringe nodes that link to the core. Interactions between nodes in the fringe, however, are not present in the resulting graph data. For example, a phone service provider may only record calls in which at least one of the participants is a customer; this can include calls between a customer and a non-customer, but not between pairs of non-customers. Knowledge of which nodes belong to the core is crucial for interpreting the dataset, but this metadata is unavailable in many cases, either because it has been lost due to difficulties in data provenance, or because the network consists of “found data” obtained in settings such as counter-surveillance. This leads to an algorithmic problem of recovering the core set. Since the core is a vertex cover, we essentially have a planted vertex cover problem, but with an arbitrary underlying graph. We develop a framework for analyzing this planted vertex cover problem, based on the theory of fixed-parameter tractability, together with algorithms for recovering the core. Our algorithms are fast, simple to implement, and out-perform several baselines based on core-periphery structure on various real-world datasets.

highlights: A graph dataset is annotated with metadata about which nodes belong to the core, and this is crucial for correctly interpreting the data
We develop a natural heuristic based on constructing a union of minimal vertex covers from random initializations
The planted vertex cover recovery algorithm that we develop in Section 3 uses the union of minimal vertex covers to identify nodes that are likely in the planted cover
We study recovery of planted vertex covers in datasets with conceivable but known core-fringe structure arising from the measurement processes described in the introduction
We examined the case where edges are collected by observing interactions involving some core set of nodes, and the identity of the core nodes is lost
We assumed that our graphs were simple and undirected, but richer structure such as edge directions and timestamps could be incorporated in future research
key_statements: A graph dataset is annotated with metadata about which nodes belong to the core, and this is crucial for correctly interpreting the data
We develop a natural heuristic based on constructing a union of minimal vertex covers from random initializations
Let U (k) be the union of all minimal vertex covers of size at most k

If C is not minimal, can we still ensure that some parts of it must be contained in U (|C|), the union of all minimal vertex covers of size at most |C|? The following propositions show that if u ∈ C links to a node v either outside C or deeply contained in C, u must belong to U (|C|)
The planted vertex cover recovery algorithm that we develop in Section 3 uses the union of minimal vertex covers to identify nodes that are likely in the planted cover
The following lemma shows that any vertex cover whose size is bounded by a multiplicative constant of k∗ must intersect the output of Algorithm 1 in a constant fraction of its nodes
With probability at least 1 − |C|−3 ln n/(2p), the union of minimal vertex covers of size at most |C| contains at most |C|(3 ln|C|/p + 3) nodes
We study recovery of planted vertex covers in datasets with conceivable but known core-fringe structure arising from the measurement processes described in the introduction
Given the ordering of nodes from an algorithm, we evaluate recovery performance by the precision at core size (P@CS; Figure 4, left) and area under the precision recall curve (AUPRC; Figure 4, right)
We examined the case where edges are collected by observing interactions involving some core set of nodes, and the identity of the core nodes is lost
We assumed that our graphs were simple and undirected, but richer structure such as edge directions and timestamps could be incorporated in future research
summary: A graph dataset is annotated with metadata about which nodes belong to the core, and this is crucial for correctly interpreting the data.
We use fixed-parameter tractability to show that there is an algorithm operating on arbitrary graphs that can output a set of f (k) nodes guaranteed to contain the planted vertex cover.
For some function f , can we find a set D of size at most f (k) that is guaranteed to contain the planted vertex cover C?
If S is the set of all nodes in G with degree greater than k, S is contained in every vertex cover of size at most k.
The following theorem, giving a positive answer to Question 2, is a corollary of Lemma 1(a) obtained by setting D = U (k), the union of all minimal vertex covers of size at most k: Theorem 1.
If C is a minimal planted vertex cover with |C| ≤ k, we can find a set D of size O(k2) that is guaranteed to contain C.
The following lemma shows that any vertex cover whose size is bounded by a multiplicative constant of k∗ must intersect the output of Algorithm 1 in a constant fraction of its nodes.
If the planted vertex cover C has size |C| ≤ ck∗, Algorithm 1 produces a set M of size ≤ 2k∗ that intersects at least a 1/(2c) fraction of the nodes in C.
We consider how to make use of random structure and bounds on the minimum vertex cover size k∗ obtained through computation with Algorithm 1 can strengthen our theoretical guarantees.
With probability at least 1 − |C|−3 ln n/(2p), the union of minimal vertex covers of size at most |C| contains at most |C|(3 ln|C|/p + 3) nodes.
We study recovery of planted vertex covers in datasets with conceivable but known core-fringe structure arising from the measurement processes described in the introduction.

Given the ordering of nodes from an algorithm, we evaluate recovery performance by the precision at core size (P@CS; Figure 4, left) and area under the precision recall curve (AUPRC; Figure 4, right).
Each algorithm orders the nodes, and we measure performance with precision at core size and area under the precision recall curve over every 10 days of real time.
headline: We develop a framework for analyzing this planted vertex cover problem, based on the theory of fixed-parameter tractability, together with algorithms for recovering the core
